title: Cyber Monday is tracking for over $12 billion in sales, the biggest online shopping day of all time

content.background: Cyber Monday continues to be the biggest online shopping day of the year, with consumers scouring the internet for online deals. Major retailers like Amazon, Target, and Walmart have extended their Cyber Monday sales over the weekend. Consumer spending during Cyber Week provides an indication of holiday season spending. Despite high inflation and increasing credit card debt, shoppers are resilient and relying on savings to fuel their shopping. The National Retail Federation expects holiday spending to grow at a slower pace compared to last year. Preliminary data indicates strong online sales on Black Friday, while in-store purchases showed more modest growth. Categories seeing the most growth include electronics, clothing, toys, and jewelry.
content.summary: Consumers are projected to spend between $12 billion and $12.4 billion on Cyber Monday, making it the biggest online shopping day of all time. Shoppers have shown resilience in the face of high inflation and increasing credit card debt. Preliminary data shows strong online sales during Black Friday and a turnaround in store traffic compared to earlier declines. Categories seeing the most growth include electronics, clothing, toys, and jewelry. The resale industry is also expected to be a significant part of the holiday shopping season. Overall, while spending is expected to slow compared to last year, consumer spending remains strong.

content.background: Spending online on Cyber Monday is projected to exceed $12 billion, a record, as bargain hunters take advantage of deals on various items. Retailers have implemented marketing strategies, including push notifications and video streaming ads, to entice shoppers. The increase in online spending is expected to be around 9.7% compared to the previous year.
content.summary: US shoppers are estimated to spend $12-$12.4 billion on Cyber Monday, with a significant portion occurring between 6 p.m. and 11 p.m. EST. Shoppers have already spent $8.3 billion online as of 6 pm EST. Retailers are hopeful that the strong consumer spending trend continues, although concerns have been raised about higher interest rates and depleted household savings. Companies like Amazon and Walmart have offered significant discounts to attract more customers.

title: US stock market: Wall St ends lower amid Cyber Monday madness

content.background: The US stock market ended lower as investors took a post-Thanksgiving pause and the holiday shopping season kicked in with Cyber Monday deals. Online shopping deals on Cyber Monday are expected to drive record consumer spending of $12 billion. Investors are focusing on economic data and consumer confidence to determine if Main Street has kept up with Wall Street. The Federal Reserve's restrictive policy and potential rate cuts are being monitored. The Dow Jones, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite all ended modestly in the red.
content.summary: Investors took a breather after recent market gains, with a focus on economic data and consumer spending during the holiday season. Online shopping deals on Cyber Monday are expected to drive record consumer spending of $12 billion. The health of the American consumer, responsible for 70% of the US GDP, remains positive. The possibility of rate cuts in 2024 is being considered. The Dow Jones, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite all ended slightly lower.

title: Cyber Monday sales set to reach $12.4 billion thanks to deal-hunters

content.background: Cyber Monday is a major shopping day in the US, known for heavily discounted products. This year, spending online on Cyber Monday is projected to reach $12.4 billion, a record-breaking figure and a 5.4% increase compared to the previous year. Amazon, Walmart, and Apple are expected to be among the top performers on this day.
content.summary: Retailers are leveraging push notifications, text messages, and video streaming ads to attract consumers on Cyber Monday. Amazon and Apple are expected to see healthy consumer demand, as they don't have to discount their products as much. However, experts predict that retailers may need to offer deeper discounts in the coming weeks, which could negatively impact profit margins. Last-minute shoppers on Cyber Monday evening are predicted to spend $4 billion. Walmart has slashed prices on clothing to 60%, while Apple is offering Apple Gift Cards with eligible purchases.

content.background: This briefing discusses the impact of Black Friday on consumer spending and its implications for the economy.
content.summary: Black Friday saw a significant increase in online sales, with $9.8 billion spent in the U.S., up 7.5% from the previous year. This surge in spending indicates a more favorable consumer mindset compared to last year when inflation was affecting wallets.
